1. Vectors in Euclidean Space

1.1 Vector Addition and Scalar Multiplication

The set Rn\mathbb{R}^{n}Rn is defined by Rn={x⃗=[x1⋮xn]:x1,...,xn∈R}\mathbb{R}^{n}=\{\vec{x}=\begin{bmatrix}x_{1}\\ \vdots\\ x_{n}\end{bmatrix}:x_{1},...,x_{n}\in\mathbb{R}\}Rn={x=​x1​⋮xn​​​:x1​,...,xn​∈R} An element x⃗∈Rn\vec{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}x∈Rn is called a vector.

Two vectors x⃗=[x1⋮xn]∈Rn\vec{x}=\begin{bmatrix}x_{1}\\ \vdots\\ x_{n}\end{bmatrix}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}x=​x1​⋮xn​​​∈Rn and y⃗=[y1⋮ym]∈Rm\vec{y}=\begin{bmatrix}y_{1}\\ \vdots\\ y_{m}\end{bmatrix}\in\mathbb{R}^{m}y​=​y1​⋮ym​​​∈Rm are said to be equal if n=mn=mn=m and xi=yix_{i}=y_{i}xi​=yi​ for 1≤i≤n1\le i\le n1≤i≤n.

e.g. For n=2n=2n=2, we have the set R2\mathbb{R}^{2}R2, for which a few elements are [12],[π1.2] and [0−10]\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 2\end{bmatrix},\begin{bmatrix}\pi\\ 1.2\end{bmatrix} \text{ and } \begin{bmatrix}0\\ -10\end{bmatrix}[12​],[π1.2​] and [0−10​] 

The set Rn\mathbb{R}^{n}Rn just defined is also known as the n-dimensional Euclidean space, which you may have already learned as the set of points (x1,...,xn)(x_{1},...,x_{n})(x1​,...,xn​). Geometrically, we will often represent the vector x⃗=[x1⋮xn]\vec{x}=\begin{bmatrix}x_{1}\\ \vdots\\ x_{n}\end{bmatrix}x=​x1​⋮xn​​​ as an arrow with its tail at the origin and its head at its corresponding point, (x1,...,xn)(x_{1},...,x_{n})(x1​,...,xn​).

Let x⃗=[x1⋮xn],y⃗=[y1⋮yn]∈Rn\vec{x}=\begin{bmatrix}x_{1}\\ \vdots\\ x_{n}\end{bmatrix}, \quad \vec{y}=\begin{bmatrix}y_{1}\\ \vdots\\ y_{n}\end{bmatrix}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}x=​x1​⋮xn​​​,y​=​y1​⋮yn​​​∈Rn and let c∈Rc\in\mathbb{R}c∈R (called a scalar). We define addition, x⃗+y⃗\vec{x}+\vec{y}x+y​, and scalar multiplication, cx⃗c\vec{x}cx, by  x⃗+y⃗=[x1+y1⋮xn+yn]andcx⃗=[cx1⋮cxn]\vec{x}+\vec{y}=\begin{bmatrix}x_{1}+y_{1}\\ \vdots\\ x_{n}+y_{n}\end{bmatrix} \quad \text{and} \quad c\vec{x}=\begin{bmatrix}cx_{1}\\ \vdots\\ cx_{n}\end{bmatrix}x+y​=​x1​+y1​⋮xn​+yn​​​andcx=​cx1​⋮cxn​​​.

Subtraction of vectors works as expected, but it is a consequence of addition and scalar multiplication. That is, x⃗−y⃗=x⃗+(−1)y⃗\vec{x}-\vec{y}=\vec{x}+(-1)\vec{y}x−y​=x+(−1)y​.

e.g. True or False?

  1. [12]=[120]\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 2\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 2\\ 0\end{bmatrix}[12​]=​120​​
  2. For x⃗∈R3\vec{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{3}x∈R3, x⃗−x⃗=0\vec{x}-\vec{x}=0x−x=0
  3. [12]−2[11]=[−10]\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 2\end{bmatrix}-2\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 1\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}-1\\ 0\end{bmatrix}[12​]−2[11​]=[−10​]

Answers:

  1. False. A vector from R2\mathbb{R}^{2}R2 is different from a vector in R3\mathbb{R}^{3}R3.
  2. False. The correct answer is [000]\begin{bmatrix}0\\ 0\\ 0\end{bmatrix}​000​​, which we can also represent as 0⃗\vec{0}0, called the zero vector.
  3. True. Here we have both addition and scalar multiplication in our first example of a linear combination, defined formally in the next slide.

For v⃗1,...,v⃗k∈Rn\vec{v}{1},...,\vec{v}{k}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}v1,...,vk∈Rn and c1,...,ck∈Rc_{1},...,c_{k}\in\mathbb{R}c1​,...,ck​∈R we call the expression c1v⃗1+⋅⋅⋅+ckv⃗kc_{1}\vec{v}_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+c_{k}\vec{v}_{k}c1​v1​+⋅⋅⋅+ck​vk​ a linear combination of v⃗1,...,v⃗k\vec{v}_{1},...,\vec{v}_{k}v1​,...,vk​.

Theorem 1.1.7

If x⃗,y⃗,w⃗∈Rn\vec{x}, \vec{y}, \vec{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}x,y​,w∈Rn and c, d∈Rd\in\mathbb{R}d∈R, then

  1. x⃗+y⃗∈Rn\vec{x}+\vec{y}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}x+y​∈Rn
  2. (x⃗+y⃗)+w⃗=x⃗+(y⃗+w⃗)(\vec{x}+\vec{y})+\vec{w}=\vec{x}+(\vec{y}+\vec{w})(x+y​)+w=x+(y​+w).
  3. x⃗+y⃗=y⃗+x⃗\vec{x}+\vec{y}=\vec{y}+\vec{x}x+y​=y​+x
  4. There exists a vector 0⃗∈Rn\vec{0}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}0∈Rn such that x⃗+0⃗=x⃗\vec{x}+\vec{0}=\vec{x}x+0=x for all x⃗∈Rn\vec{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}x∈Rn.
  5. For x⃗∈Rn\vec{x}\in R^{n}x∈Rn there exists (−x⃗)∈Rn(-\vec{x})\in\mathbb{R}^{n}(−x)∈Rn such that x⃗+(−x⃗)=0⃗\vec{x}+(-\vec{x})=\vec{0}x+(−x)=0.
  6. cx⃗∈Rnc\vec{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}cx∈Rn.
  7. c(dx⃗)=(cd)x⃗c(d\vec{x})=(cd)\vec{x}c(dx)=(cd)x
  8. (c+d)x⃗=cx⃗+dx⃗(c+d)\vec{x}=c\vec{x}+d\vec{x}(c+d)x=cx+dx.
  9. c(x⃗+y⃗)=cx⃗+cy⃗c(\vec{x}+\vec{y})=c\vec{x}+c\vec{y}c(x+y​)=cx+cy​.
  10. 1x⃗=x⃗1\vec{x}=\vec{x}1x=x

1.2 Bases

Let B={v⃗1,...,v⃗k}\mathcal{B}=\{\vec{v}{1},...,\vec{v}{k}\}B={v1,...,vk} be a set of vectors in Rn\mathbb{R}^{n}Rn. We define the span of B\mathcal{B}B by Span B={c1v⃗1+⋅⋅⋅+ckv⃗k∣c1,...,ck∈R}.\text{Span } \mathcal{B}=\{c_{1}\vec{v}{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+c{k}\vec{v}{k}|c{1},...,c_{k}\in\mathbb{R}\}.Span B={c1​v1+⋅⋅⋅+ckvk∣c1,...,ck​∈R}. We say that the set Span B\mathcal{B}B is spanned by B\mathcal{B}B and that B\mathcal{B}B is a spanning set for Span B\mathcal{B}B.

e.g. Let e⃗1=[10]\vec{e}_{1}=\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 0\end{bmatrix}e1​=[10​]. The set Span{e⃗1}Span\{\vec{e}_{1}\}Span{e1​} would contain, for example, the vectors [00],[30]and[π0]but not [0−1]\begin{bmatrix}0\\ 0\end{bmatrix},\begin{bmatrix}3\\ 0\end{bmatrix} \quad \text{and} \quad \begin{bmatrix}\pi\\ 0\end{bmatrix} \quad \text{but not } \quad \begin{bmatrix}0\\ -1\end{bmatrix}[00​],[30​]and[π0​]but not [0−1​]

e.g. Let e⃗1=[10]\vec{e}{1}=\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 0\end{bmatrix}e1=[10​], e⃗2=[01]\vec{e}{2}=\begin{bmatrix}0\\ 1\end{bmatrix}e2=[01​], and B={e⃗1,e⃗2}\mathcal{B}=\{\vec{e}{1},\vec{e}{2}\}B={e1,e2}. How would you describe the set Span B\mathcal{B}B? Answer: all the vectors in R2\mathbb{R}^{2}R2.

e.g. Now, how would you describe the set Span {[10],[20],[01]}\text{Span } \{[\begin{matrix}1\\ 0\end{matrix}],[\begin{matrix}2\\ 0\end{matrix}],[\begin{matrix}0\\ 1\end{matrix}]\}Span {[10​],[20​],[01​]} Answer: all of R2\mathbb{R}^{2}R2. ( [20]=2[10]→a[10]+G[01][\begin{smallmatrix}2\\ 0\end{smallmatrix}]=2[\begin{smallmatrix}1\\ 0\end{smallmatrix}] \rightarrow a[\begin{smallmatrix}1\\ 0\end{smallmatrix}]+G[\begin{smallmatrix}0\\ 1\end{smallmatrix}][20​]=2[10​]→a[10​]+G[01​]).

Theorem 1.2.10

Let v⃗1,...,v⃗k∈Rn\vec{v}_{1},..., \vec{v}_{k}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}v1​,...,vk​∈Rn. Some vector v⃗j\vec{v}_{j}vj​, 1≤j≤k1\le j\le k1≤j≤k, can be written as a linear combination of v⃗1\vec{v}_{1}v1​,..., v⃗j−1,\vec{v}_{j-1},vj−1​, v⃗j+1\vec{v}_{j+1}vj+1​,..., v⃗k\vec{v}_{k}vk​ if and only if Span{v⃗1,...,v⃗k}=Span{v⃗1,...,v⃗j−1,v⃗j+1,...,v⃗k}\text{Span}\{\vec{v}_{1},...,\vec{v}_{k}\}=\text{Span}\{\vec{v}_{1},...,\vec{v}_{j-1},\vec{v}_{j+1},...,\vec{v}_{k}\}Span{v1​,...,vk​}=Span{v1​,...,vj−1​,vj+1​,...,vk​}.

Note: A direct application of the theorem above to Activity 2 suggests that [20]\begin{bmatrix}2\\ 0\end{bmatrix}[20​] can be written as a linear combination of e⃗1\vec{e}_{1}e1​ and e⃗2\vec{e}_{2}e2​. (Note: The text means [10]\begin{bmatrix}1\\0\end{bmatrix}[10​] and [01]\begin{bmatrix}0\\1\end{bmatrix}[01​] for e⃗1,e⃗2\vec{e}_1, \vec{e}_2e1​,e2​. The vector[20]\begin{bmatrix}2\\0\end{bmatrix}[20​] is a linear combination of just[10]\begin{bmatrix}1\\0\end{bmatrix}[10​].) Can[10]\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 0\end{bmatrix}[10​] be written as a linear combination of [20]\begin{bmatrix}2\\ 0\end{bmatrix}[20​] and [01]\begin{bmatrix}0\\ 1\end{bmatrix}[01​]? Yes!

A set of vectors {v⃗1,...,v⃗k}\{\vec{v}_{1},...,\vec{v}_{k}\}{v1​,...,vk​} in Rn\mathbb{R}^{n}Rn is said to be linearly dependent if there exists coefficients c1,...,ckc_{1},...,c_{k}c1​,...,ck​ not all zero such that 0⃗=c1v⃗1+⋅⋅⋅+ckv⃗k\vec{0}=c_{1}\vec{v}_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+c_{k}\vec{v}_{k}0=c1​v1​+⋅⋅⋅+ck​vk​

A set of vectors {v⃗1,...,v⃗k}\{\vec{v}_{1},...,\vec{v}_{k}\}{v1​,...,vk​} in Rn\mathbb{R}^{n}Rn is said to be linearly independent if the only solution to 0⃗=c1v⃗1+⋅⋅⋅+ckv⃗k\vec{0}=c_{1}\vec{v}_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+c_{k}\vec{v}_{k}0=c1​v1​+⋅⋅⋅+ck​vk​, is c1=⋅⋅⋅=ck=0c_{1}=\cdot\cdot\cdot=c_{k}=0c1​=⋅⋅⋅=ck​=0 (called the trivial solution).

e.g. {[10],[01]}\{\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 0\end{bmatrix},\begin{bmatrix}0\\ 1\end{bmatrix}\}{[10​],[01​]} is a linearly independent set. But, [20]=2[10]\begin{bmatrix}2\\ 0\end{bmatrix}=2\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 0\end{bmatrix}[20​]=2[10​], so adding it to any set that already contains [10]\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 0\end{bmatrix}[10​] makes the set linearly dependent.

e.g. Is {[13],[4−2],[1−11]}\{[\begin{matrix}1\\ 3\end{matrix}],[\begin{matrix}4\\ -2\end{matrix}],[\begin{matrix}1\\ -11\end{matrix}]\}{[13​],[4−2​],[1−11​]} linearly independent? Answer: No, since −3[13]+1[4−2]−1[1−11]=[00]-3\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 3\end{bmatrix}+1\begin{bmatrix}4\\ -2\end{bmatrix}-1\begin{bmatrix}1\\ -11\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}0\\ 0\end{bmatrix}−3[13​]+1[4−2​]−1[1−11​]=[00​]. This is equivalent to [1−11]=−3[13]+1[4−2]\begin{bmatrix}1\\ -11\end{bmatrix}=-3\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 3\end{bmatrix}+1\begin{bmatrix}4\\ -2\end{bmatrix}[1−11​]=−3[13​]+1[4−2​]. So, by Theorem 1.2.10, Span{[13],[4−2],[1−11]}=Span{[13],[4−2]}\text{Span}\{[\begin{matrix}1\\ 3\end{matrix}],[\begin{matrix}4\\ -2\end{matrix}],[\begin{matrix}1\\ -11\end{matrix}]\}=\text{Span}\{[\begin{matrix}1\\ 3\end{matrix}],[\begin{matrix}4\\ -2\end{matrix}]\}Span{[13​],[4−2​],[1−11​]}=Span{[13​],[4−2​]}.

Theorem 1.2.13 A set of vectors {v⃗1,...,v⃗k}\{\vec{v}_{1},...,\vec{v}_{k}\}{v1​,...,vk​} in Rn\mathbb{R}^{n}Rn is said to be linearly dependent if and only if v⃗i∈Span{v⃗1,...,v⃗i−1,v⃗i+1,...,v⃗k}\vec{v}_{i}\in \text{Span}\{\vec{v}_{1},...,\vec{v}_{i-1},\vec{v}_{i+1},...,\vec{v}_{k}\}vi​∈Span{v1​,...,vi−1​,vi+1​,...,vk​}, for some i, with 1≤i≤k1\le i\le k1≤i≤k.

Theorem 1.2.20 If a set of vectors {v⃗1,...,v⃗k}\{\vec{v}_{1},...,\vec{v}_{k}\}{v1​,...,vk​} contains the zero vector, then it is linearly dependent.

e.g. The set B={[10],[01]}\mathcal{B}=\{[\begin{matrix}1\\ 0\end{matrix}],[\begin{matrix}0\\ 1\end{matrix}]\}B={[10​],[01​]} is a basis for R2\mathbb{R}^{2}R2. First, c1[10]+c2[01]=[c1c2]=[00]c_{1}\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 0\end{bmatrix}+c_{2}\begin{bmatrix}0\\ 1\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}c_{1}\\ c_{2}\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}0\\ 0\end{bmatrix}c1​[10​]+c2​[01​]=[c1​c2​​]=[00​] only if c1=c2=0c_{1}=c_{2}=0c1​=c2​=0 so B\mathcal{B}B is linearly independent. Second, for any vector x⃗=[xy]∈R2\vec{x}=\begin{bmatrix}x\\ y\end{bmatrix}\in\mathbb{R}^{2}x=[xy​]∈R2, we have that x⃗\vec{x}x can be written as a linear combination of the vectors of B\mathcal{B}B in the form: [xy]=x[10]+y[01]\begin{bmatrix}x\\ y\end{bmatrix}=x\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 0\end{bmatrix}+y\begin{bmatrix}0\\ 1\end{bmatrix}[xy​]=x[10​]+y[01​] Thus, x⃗∈SpanB\vec{x}\in \text{Span}\mathcal{B}x∈SpanB which implies that R2⊆Span B\mathbb{R}^{2} \subseteq \text{Span } \mathcal{B}R2⊆Span B. Finally, for any c1,c2∈Rc_{1}, c_{2}\in\mathbb{R}c1​,c2​∈R, the vector c1[10]+c2[01]=[c1c2]∈R2c_{1}\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 0\end{bmatrix}+c_{2}\begin{bmatrix}0\\ 1\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}c_{1}\\ c_{2}\end{bmatrix}\in\mathbb{R}^{2}c1​[10​]+c2​[01​]=[c1​c2​​]∈R2, so Span B⊆R2\text{Span } \mathcal{B}\subseteq\mathbb{R}^{2}Span B⊆R2 and R2=SpanB\mathbb{R}^{2}=\text{Span}\mathcal{B}R2=SpanB.

e.g. Write down the standard basis for R4\mathbb{R}^{4}R4. Answer: {[1000],[0100],[0010],[0001]}\{\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 0\\ 0\\ 0\end{bmatrix},\begin{bmatrix}0\\ 1\\ 0\\ 0\end{bmatrix},\begin{bmatrix}0\\ 0\\ 1\\ 0\end{bmatrix},\begin{bmatrix}0\\ 0\\ 0\\ 1\end{bmatrix}\}{​1000​​,​0100​​,​0010​​,​0001​​}

e.g. Is the set B={[101],[−211]}\mathcal{B}=\{[\begin{matrix}1\\ 0\\ 1\end{matrix}],[\begin{matrix}-2\\ 1\\ 1\end{matrix}]\}B={[101​],[−211​]} a basis for R3\mathbb{R}^{3}R3? Answer: No, consider the vector e⃗1=[100]∈R3\vec{e}_{1}=\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 0\\ 0\end{bmatrix}\in\mathbb{R}^{3}e1​=​100​​∈R3 and note that e⃗1∉SpanB\vec{e}_{1}\notin \text{Span}\mathcal{B}e1​∈/SpanB.

1.3 Subspaces

A subset S\mathbb{S}S of Rn\mathbb{R}^{n}Rn is called a subspace of Rn\mathbb{R}^{n}Rn if for every x⃗,y⃗,w⃗∈S\vec{x}, \vec{y}, \vec{w}\in\mathbb{S}x,y​,w∈S and c, d∈Rd\in\mathbb{R}d∈R we have

  1. x⃗+y⃗∈S\vec{x}+\vec{y}\in\mathbb{S}x+y​∈S.
  2. (x⃗+y⃗)+w⃗=x⃗+(y⃗+w⃗)(\vec{x}+\vec{y})+\vec{w}=\vec{x}+(\vec{y}+\vec{w})(x+y​)+w=x+(y​+w)
  3. x⃗+y⃗=y⃗+x⃗\vec{x}+\vec{y}=\vec{y}+\vec{x}x+y​=y​+x.
  4. There exists a vector 0⃗∈S\vec{0}\in\mathbb{S}0∈S such that x⃗+0⃗=x⃗\vec{x}+\vec{0}=\vec{x}x+0=x for all x⃗∈S\vec{x}\in\mathbb{S}x∈S.
  5. For every x⃗∈S\vec{x}\in\mathbb{S}x∈S there exists (−x⃗)∈S(-\vec{x})\in\mathbb{S}(−x)∈S such that x⃗+(−x⃗)=0⃗\vec{x}+(-\vec{x})=\vec{0}x+(−x)=0.
  6. cx⃗∈Sc\vec{x}\in\mathbb{S}cx∈S
  7. c(dx⃗)=(cd)x⃗c(d\vec{x})=(cd)\vec{x}c(dx)=(cd)x
  8. (c+d)x⃗=cx⃗+dx⃗(c+d)\vec{x}=c\vec{x}+d\vec{x}(c+d)x=cx+dx
  9. c(x⃗+y⃗)=cx⃗+cy⃗c(\vec{x}+\vec{y})=c\vec{x}+c\vec{y}c(x+y​)=cx+cy​.
  10. 1x⃗=x⃗1\vec{x}=\vec{x}1x=x

Subspace Test Let S be a non-empty subset of Rn\mathbb{R}^{n}Rn. If x⃗+y⃗∈S\vec{x}+\vec{y}\in\mathbb{S}x+y​∈S and cx⃗∈Sc\vec{x}\in\mathbb{S}cx∈S for all x⃗,y⃗∈S\vec{x}, \vec{y}\in\mathbb{S}x,y​∈S and c∈Rc\in\mathbb{R}c∈R, then S is a subspace of Rn\mathbb{R}^{n}Rn.

Subspace Test:

  1. Contains 0⃗\vec{0}0
  2. Close addition
  3. Close scalar multiplication.

e.g. Show that the line L given by Span {[11]}\{[\begin{matrix}1\\ 1\end{matrix}]\}{[11​]} is a subspace of R2\mathbb{R}^{2}R2. Answer: The line L is a non-empty subset of R2\mathbb{R}^{2}R2, since 0[11]=0⃗∈L0\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 1\end{bmatrix}=\vec{0}\in L0[11​]=0∈L. Let x⃗,y⃗∈L\vec{x}, \vec{y}\in Lx,y​∈L, that is, x⃗=c1[11]\vec{x}=c_{1}\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 1\end{bmatrix}x=c1​[11​] and y⃗=c2[11]\vec{y}=c_{2}\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 1\end{bmatrix}y​=c2​[11​] for some c1,c2∈Rc_{1}, c_{2}\in\mathbb{R}c1​,c2​∈R. Thus, for any c∈Rc\in\mathbb{R}c∈R, x⃗+y⃗=(c1+c2)[11]∈Landcx⃗=(cc1)[11]∈L\vec{x}+\vec{y}=(c_{1}+c_{2})\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 1\end{bmatrix}\in L \quad \text{and} \quad c\vec{x}=(cc_{1})\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 1\end{bmatrix}\in Lx+y​=(c1​+c2​)[11​]∈Landcx=(cc1​)[11​]∈L.

e.g. Let L be a line in Rn\mathbb{R}^{n}Rn with vector equation x⃗=tv⃗+b⃗,\vec{x}=t\vec{v}+\vec{b},x=tv+b, t∈Rt\in\mathbb{R}t∈R. If {v⃗,b⃗}\{\vec{v},\vec{b}\}{v,b} linearly independent, can L be a subspace of Rn\mathbb{R}^{n}Rn? Answer: No. b⃗\vec{b}b has to equal 0⃗\vec{0}0 to contain 0⃗\vec{0}0.

If v⃗1,...,v⃗k∈Rn\vec{v}_{1},...,\vec{v}_{k}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}v1​,...,vk​∈Rn, then S=Span{v⃗1,...,v⃗k}\mathbb{S}=\text{Span}\{\vec{v}_{1},...,\vec{v}_{k}\}S=Span{v1​,...,vk​} is a subspace of Rn\mathbb{R}^{n}Rn.

About this theorem:

  1. Is {v⃗1,...,v⃗k}\{\vec{v}_{1},...,\vec{v}_{k}\}{v1​,...,vk​} a basis for the subspace S of Rn\mathbb{R}^{n}Rn? Not necessarily, since a basis has to be linearly independent.
  2. If {v⃗1,...,v⃗k}\{\vec{v}_{1},...,\vec{v}_{k}\}{v1​,...,vk​} is indeed linearly independent, then it would be a basis for S. In that case, we would say that the dimension of S is k according to the definition below.

The dimension of S⊆Rn\mathbb{S}\subseteq\mathbb{R}^{n}S⊆Rn, denoted by dim S, is defined as the number of vectors in any basis for S.

e.g. Find a basis for the subspace S1={[x1x2x3]∈R3∣x1−2x3=0,x2+4x3=0}\mathbb{S}{1}=\{[\begin{matrix}x{1}\\ x_{2}\\ x_{3}\end{matrix}]\in\mathbb{R}^{3}|x_{1}-2x_{3}=0,x_{2}+4x_{3}=0\}S1={[x1x2​x3​​]∈R3∣x1​−2x3​=0,x2​+4x3​=0} of R3\mathbb{R}^{3}R3. Answer: The equations that help define S1\mathbb{S}{1}S1 imply that x1−2x3=0⇒x1=2x3x{1}-2x_{3}=0\Rightarrow x_{1}=2x_{3}x1−2x3​=0⇒x1​=2x3​ x2+4x3=0⇒x2=−4x3x_{2}+4x_{3}=0\Rightarrow x_{2}=-4x_{3}x2​+4x3​=0⇒x2​=−4x3​ Thus, for any vector in S1\mathbb{S}{1}S1 [x1x2x3]=[2x3−4x3x3]=x3[2−41], let v⃗=[2−41]\begin{bmatrix}x{1}\\ x_{2}\\ x_{3}\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}2x_{3}\\ -4x_{3}\\ x_{3}\end{bmatrix}=x_{3}\begin{bmatrix}2\\ -4\\ 1\end{bmatrix}, \text{ let } \vec{v}=\begin{bmatrix}2\\ -4\\ 1\end{bmatrix}​x1x2​x3​​​=​2x3​−4x3​x3​​​=x3​​2−41​​, let v=​2−41​​ That is, S1⊆Span{v⃗}\mathbb{S}{1}\subseteq \text{Span}\{\vec{v}\}S1⊆Span{v}. We can also check that Span{v⃗}⊆S1\text{Span}\{\vec{v}\}\subseteq\mathbb{S}{1}Span{v}⊆S1, so {v⃗}\{\vec{v}\}{v} is a basis for S1\mathbb{S}{1}S1. Furthermore, dimS1=1dim\mathbb{S}{1}=1dimS1=1.

1.4 Dot Product, Cross Product, and Scalar Equations

Let x⃗=[x1⋮xn]andy⃗=[y1⋮yn]\vec{x}=\begin{bmatrix}x_{1}\\ \vdots\\ x_{n}\end{bmatrix} \quad \text{and} \quad \vec{y}=\begin{bmatrix}y_{1}\\ \vdots\\ y_{n}\end{bmatrix}x=​x1​⋮xn​​​andy​=​y1​⋮yn​​​ be vectors in Rn\mathbb{R}^{n}Rn. The dot product of x⃗\vec{x}x and y⃗\vec{y}y​ is x⃗⋅y⃗=[x1⋮xn]⋅[y1⋮yn]=x1y1+⋅⋅⋅+xnyn=∑i=1nxiyi\vec{x}\cdot\vec{y}=\begin{bmatrix}x_{1}\\ \vdots\\ x_{n}\end{bmatrix}\cdot\begin{bmatrix}y_{1}\\ \vdots\\ y_{n}\end{bmatrix}=x_{1}y_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+x_{n}y_{n}=\sum_{i=1}^{n}x_{i}y_{i}x⋅y​=​x1​⋮xn​​​⋅​y1​⋮yn​​​=x1​y1​+⋅⋅⋅+xn​yn​=∑i=1n​xi​yi​. In R2\mathbb{R}^{2}R2 and R3\mathbb{R}^{3}R3, the dot product is simply [x1x2]⋅[y1y2]=x1y1+x2y2\begin{bmatrix}x_{1}\\ x_{2}\end{bmatrix}\cdot\begin{bmatrix}y_{1}\\ y_{2}\end{bmatrix}=x_{1}y_{1}+x_{2}y_{2}[x1​x2​​]⋅[y1​y2​​]=x1​y1​+x2​y2​. [x1x2x3]⋅[y1y2y3]=x1y1+x2y2+x3y3\begin{bmatrix}x_{1}\\ x_{2}\\ x_{3}\end{bmatrix}\cdot\begin{bmatrix}y_{1}\\ y_{2}\\ y_{3}\end{bmatrix}=x_{1}y_{1}+x_{2}y_{2}+x_{3}y_{3}​x1​x2​x3​​​⋅​y1​y2​y3​​​=x1​y1​+x2​y2​+x3​y3​.

e.g. Consider x⃗=[123]\vec{x}=\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 2\\ 3\end{bmatrix}x=​123​​, y⃗=[211]\vec{y}=\begin{bmatrix}2\\ 1\\ 1\end{bmatrix}y​=​211​​, and z⃗=[1005]\vec{z}=\begin{bmatrix}10\\ 0\\ 5\end{bmatrix}z=​1005​​, and compute (x⃗⋅y⃗)z⃗(\vec{x}\cdot\vec{y})\vec{z}(x⋅y​)z. Answer: x⃗⋅y⃗=[123]⋅[211]=2+2+3=7\vec{x}\cdot\vec{y}=\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 2\\ 3\end{bmatrix}\cdot\begin{bmatrix}2\\ 1\\ 1\end{bmatrix}=2+2+3=7x⋅y​=​123​​⋅​211​​=2+2+3=7. (x⃗⋅y⃗)z⃗=7z⃗=7[1005]=[70035](\vec{x}\cdot\vec{y})\vec{z}=7\vec{z}=7\begin{bmatrix}10\\ 0\\ 5\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}70\\ 0\\ 35\end{bmatrix}(x⋅y​)z=7z=7​1005​​=​70035​​.

Theorem 1.4.8 If x⃗,y⃗,z⃗∈Rn\vec{x}, \vec{y}, \vec{z}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}x,y​,z∈Rn and s,t∈Rs, t\in\mathbb{R}s,t∈R, then

  1. x⃗⋅x⃗≥0\vec{x}\cdot\vec{x}\ge0x⋅x≥0, and x⃗⋅x⃗=0\vec{x}\cdot\vec{x}=0x⋅x=0 if and only if x⃗=0⃗\vec{x}=\vec{0}x=0.
  2. x⃗⋅y⃗=y⃗⋅x⃗\vec{x}\cdot\vec{y}=\vec{y}\cdot\vec{x}x⋅y​=y​⋅x.
  3. x⃗⋅(sy⃗+tz⃗)=s(x⃗⋅y⃗)+t(x⃗⋅z⃗)\vec{x}\cdot(s\vec{y}+t\vec{z})=s(\vec{x}\cdot\vec{y})+t(\vec{x}\cdot\vec{z})x⋅(sy​+tz)=s(x⋅y​)+t(x⋅z).

Let x⃗∈Rn\vec{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}x∈Rn. The length or norm of x⃗\vec{x}x is defined to be ∣∣x⃗∣∣=x⃗⋅x⃗||\vec{x}||=\sqrt{\vec{x}\cdot\vec{x}}∣∣x∣∣=x⋅x​

e.g. Find the length of x⃗=[12]\vec{x}=\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 2\end{bmatrix}x=[12​] and y⃗=[122]\vec{y}=\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 2\\ 2\end{bmatrix}y​=​122​​. Answer: ∣∣x⃗∣∣=x⃗⋅x⃗=12+22=5||\vec{x}||=\sqrt{\vec{x}\cdot\vec{x}}=\sqrt{1^{2}+2^{2}}=\sqrt{5}∣∣x∣∣=x⋅x​=12+22​=5​ ∣∣y⃗∣∣=y⃗⋅y⃗=12+22+22=9=3||\vec{y}||=\sqrt{\vec{y}\cdot\vec{y}}=\sqrt{1^{2}+2^{2}+2^{2}}=\sqrt{9}=3∣∣y​∣∣=y​⋅y​​=12+22+22​=9​=3

A vector x⃗∈Rn\vec{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}x∈Rn such that ∣∣x⃗∣∣=1||\vec{x}||=1∣∣x∣∣=1 is called a unit vector. Note: All vectors from the standard bases, e⃗i\vec{e}_{i}ei​, are unit vectors.

Theorem 1.4.8 (Note: Same theorem number as previous, likely continuation of properties) If x⃗,y⃗∈Rn\vec{x}, \vec{y}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}x,y​∈Rn and c∈Rc\in\mathbb{R}c∈R then

  1. ∣∣x⃗∣∣≥0||\vec{x}||\ge0∣∣x∣∣≥0, and ∣∣x⃗∣∣=0||\vec{x}||=0∣∣x∣∣=0 if and only if x⃗=0⃗\vec{x}=\vec{0}x=0.
  2. ∣∣cx⃗∣∣=∣c∣∣∣x⃗∣∣||c\vec{x}||=|c|||\vec{x}||∣∣cx∣∣=∣c∣∣∣x∣∣.
  3. ∣x⃗⋅y⃗∣≤∣∣x⃗∣∣∣∣y⃗∣∣|\vec{x}\cdot\vec{y}|\le||\vec{x}||||\vec{y}||∣x⋅y​∣≤∣∣x∣∣∣∣y​∣∣. (Cauchy-Schwarz Inequality)
  4. |∣x⃗+y⃗∣∣≤∣∣x⃗∣∣+∣∣y⃗∣∣|\vec{x}+\vec{y}||\le||\vec{x}||+||\vec{y}||∣x+y​∣∣≤∣∣x∣∣+∣∣y​∣∣. (Triangle Inequality)

Let x⃗,y⃗∈Rn\vec{x}, \vec{y}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}x,y​∈Rn. If x⃗≠0⃗\vec{x}\ne\vec{0}x=0 and y⃗≠0⃗\vec{y}\ne\vec{0}y​=0, we define an angle between x⃗\vec{x}x and y⃗\vec{y}y​ to be any θ∈R\theta\in\mathbb{R}θ∈R such that x⃗⋅y⃗=∣∣x⃗∣∣∣∣y⃗∣∣cos⁡θ\vec{x}\cdot\vec{y}=||\vec{x}||||\vec{y}||\cos\thetax⋅y​=∣∣x∣∣∣∣y​∣∣cosθ We do not define an angle between the zero vector and any other vector.

e.g. Determine the angle between the vectors v⃗=[011]\vec{v}=\begin{bmatrix}0\\ 1\\ 1\end{bmatrix}v=​011​​ and w⃗=[001]\vec{w}=\begin{bmatrix}0\\ 0\\ 1\end{bmatrix}w=​001​​. Answer: The definition of angle states that v⃗⋅w⃗=∣∣v⃗∣∣∣∣w⃗∣∣cos⁡θ\vec{v}\cdot\vec{w}=||\vec{v}||||\vec{w}||\cos\thetav⋅w=∣∣v∣∣∣∣w∣∣cosθ where v⃗⋅w⃗=0+0+1=1\vec{v}\cdot\vec{w}=0+0+1=1v⋅w=0+0+1=1, ∣∣v⃗∣∣=02+12+12=2||\vec{v}||=\sqrt{0^{2}+1^{2}+1^{2}}=\sqrt{2}∣∣v∣∣=02+12+12​=2​ and ∣∣w⃗∣∣=02+02+12=1||\vec{w}||=\sqrt{0^{2}+0^{2}+1^{2}}=1∣∣w∣∣=02+02+12​=1. Thus, 1=2cos⁡θ⇒cos⁡θ=12⇒θ=π41=\sqrt{2}\cos\theta\Rightarrow \cos\theta=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\Rightarrow\theta=\frac{\pi}{4}1=2​cosθ⇒cosθ=2​1​⇒θ=4π​.

Let x⃗,y⃗∈Rn\vec{x}, \vec{y}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}x,y​∈Rn. If x⃗⋅y⃗=0\vec{x}\cdot\vec{y}=0x⋅y​=0, then x⃗\vec{x}x and y⃗\vec{y}y​ are said to be orthogonal.

e.g. The vectors [123]\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 2\\ 3\end{bmatrix}​123​​ and[11−1]\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 1\\ -1\end{bmatrix}​11−1​​ are orthogonal. (Verification: 1(1)+2(1)+3(−1)=1+2−3=01(1)+2(1)+3(-1) = 1+2-3=01(1)+2(1)+3(−1)=1+2−3=0)

A set of vectors {v⃗1,...,v⃗k}\{\vec{v}_{1},...,\vec{v}_{k}\}{v1​,...,vk​} in Rn\mathbb{R}^{n}Rn is called an orthogonal set if v⃗i⋅v⃗j=0\vec{v}{i}\cdot\vec{v}{j}=0vi⋅vj=0 for all i≠ji\ne ji=j.

e.g. The standard basis of Rn\mathbb{R}^{n}Rn is an orthogonal set.

Let v⃗,w⃗∈R3\vec{v}, \vec{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{3}v,w∈R3. The cross product of v⃗=[v1v2v3]\vec{v}=\begin{bmatrix}v_{1}\\ v_{2}\\ v_{3}\end{bmatrix}v=​v1​v2​v3​​​ and w⃗=[w1w2w3]\vec{w}=\begin{bmatrix}w_{1}\\ w_{2}\\ w_{3}\end{bmatrix}w=​w1​w2​w3​​​ is defined to be v⃗×w⃗=[v2w3−v3w2−(v1w3−v3w1)v1w2−v2w1]\vec{v}\times\vec{w}=\begin{bmatrix}v_{2}w_{3}-v_{3}w_{2}\\ -(v_{1}w_{3}-v_{3}w_{1})\\ v_{1}w_{2}-v_{2}w_{1}\end{bmatrix}v×w=​v2​w3​−v3​w2​−(v1​w3​−v3​w1​)v1​w2​−v2​w1​​​ (Note: The middle component is often written as v3w1−v1w3v_{3}w_{1}-v_{1}w_{3}v3​w1​−v1​w3​ to avoid the leading negative sign.)

Theorem 1.4.17 Suppose that v⃗,w⃗,x⃗∈R3\vec{v}, \vec{w}, \vec{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{3}v,w,x∈R3 and c∈Rc\in\mathbb{R}c∈R.

If n⃗=v⃗×w⃗\vec{n}=\vec{v}\times\vec{w}n=v×w then for any y⃗∈Span{v⃗,w⃗}\vec{y}\in \text{Span}\{\vec{v},\vec{w}\}y​∈Span{v,w} we have y⃗⋅n⃗=0\vec{y}\cdot\vec{n}=0y​⋅n=0.

  1. v⃗×w⃗=−w⃗×v⃗\vec{v}\times\vec{w}=-\vec{w}\times\vec{v}v×w=−w×v.
  2. v⃗×v⃗=0⃗\vec{v}\times\vec{v}=\vec{0}v×v=0.
  3. v⃗×w⃗=0⃗\vec{v}\times\vec{w}=\vec{0}v×w=0 if and only if either v⃗=0⃗\vec{v}=\vec{0}v=0 or w⃗\vec{w}w is a scalar multiple of v⃗\vec{v}v.
  4. v⃗×(w⃗+x⃗)=v⃗×w⃗+v⃗×x⃗\vec{v}\times(\vec{w}+\vec{x})=\vec{v}\times\vec{w}+\vec{v}\times\vec{x}v×(w+x)=v×w+v×x.
  5. (cv⃗)×(w⃗)=c(v⃗×w⃗)(c\vec{v})\times(\vec{w})=c(\vec{v}\times\vec{w})(cv)×(w)=c(v×w).
  6. ∣∣v⃗×w⃗∣∣=∣∣v⃗∣∣∣∣w⃗∣∣sin⁡θ∣||\vec{v}\times\vec{w}||=||\vec{v}||||\vec{w}||\sin\theta|∣∣v×w∣∣=∣∣v∣∣∣∣w∣∣sinθ∣ where θ\thetaθ is the angle between v⃗\vec{v}v and w⃗\vec{w}w.

Theorem 1.4.18 Let v⃗,w⃗,b⃗∈R3\vec{v}, \vec{w}, \vec{b}\in\mathbb{R}^{3}v,w,b∈R3 with {v⃗,w⃗}\{\vec{v},\vec{w}\}{v,w} being linearly independent and let P be a plane in R3\mathbb{R}^{3}R3 with vector equation x⃗=sv⃗+tw⃗+b⃗\vec{x}=s\vec{v}+t\vec{w}+\vec{b}x=sv+tw+b, s,t∈Rs, t\in\mathbb{R}s,t∈R. If n⃗=v⃗×w⃗\vec{n}=\vec{v}\times\vec{w}n=v×w, then an equation for the plane is (x⃗−b⃗)⋅n⃗=0(\vec{x}-\vec{b})\cdot\vec{n}=0(x−b)⋅n=0.

e.g. Let v⃗=[100]\vec{v}=\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 0\\ 0\end{bmatrix}v=​100​​, w⃗=[010]\vec{w}=\begin{bmatrix}0\\ 1\\ 0\end{bmatrix}w=​010​​ and b⃗=[000]\vec{b}=\begin{bmatrix}0\\ 0\\ 0\end{bmatrix}b=​000​​. Then n⃗=v⃗×w⃗=[001]\vec{n}=\vec{v}\times\vec{w}=\begin{bmatrix}0\\ 0\\ 1\end{bmatrix}n=v×w=​001​​ as seen in activity 1. If the plane P is given by x⃗=sv⃗+tw⃗+b⃗\vec{x}=s\vec{v}+t\vec{w}+\vec{b}x=sv+tw+b, s,t∈Rs, t\in\mathbb{R}s,t∈R, then an equation for the plane is (x⃗−b⃗)⋅n⃗=0⇒([x1x2x3]−[000])⋅[001]=0⇒x3=0(\vec{x}-\vec{b})\cdot\vec{n}=0\Rightarrow\left(\begin{bmatrix}x_{1}\\ x_{2}\\ x_{3}\end{bmatrix}-\begin{bmatrix}0\\ 0\\ 0\end{bmatrix}\right)\cdot\begin{bmatrix}0\\ 0\\ 1\end{bmatrix}=0\Rightarrow x_{3}=0(x−b)⋅n=0⇒​​x1​x2​x3​​​−​000​​​⋅​001​​=0⇒x3​=0

Let P be a plane in R3\mathbb{R}^{3}R3 that passes through the point B(b1,b2,b3)B(b_{1},b_{2},b_{3})B(b1​,b2​,b3​). If n⃗=[n1n2n3]∈R3\vec{n}=\begin{bmatrix}n_{1}\\ n_{2}\\ n_{3}\end{bmatrix}\in\mathbb{R}^{3}n=​n1​n2​n3​​​∈R3 is a vector such that n1x1+n2x2+n3x3=b1n1+b2n2+b3n3(1)n_{1}x_{1}+n_{2}x_{2}+n_{3}x_{3}=b_{1}n_{1}+b_{2}n_{2}+b_{3}n_{3} \quad (1)n1​x1​+n2​x2​+n3​x3​=b1​n1​+b2​n2​+b3​n3​(1) is an equation for P, then n⃗\vec{n}n is called a normal vector for P. We call equation (1) a scalar equation of P.

e.g. Find a scalar equation of the plane through B(0,−1,1)B(0,-1,1)B(0,−1,1) with normal vector n⃗=[123]\vec{n}=\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 2\\ 3\end{bmatrix}n=​123​​. By definition a scalar equation of the plane is n1x1+n2x2+n3x3=b1n1+b2n2+b3n3n_{1}x_{1}+n_{2}x_{2}+n_{3}x_{3}=b_{1}n_{1}+b_{2}n_{2}+b_{3}n_{3}n1​x1​+n2​x2​+n3​x3​=b1​n1​+b2​n2​+b3​n3​ 1x1+2x2+3x3=1(0)+2(−1)+3(1)=11x_{1}+2x_{2}+3x_{3}=1(0)+2(-1)+3(1)=11x1​+2x2​+3x3​=1(0)+2(−1)+3(1)=1.

Let u⃗,v⃗∈Rn\vec{u}, \vec{v}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}u,v∈Rn with v⃗≠0⃗\vec{v}\ne\vec{0}v=0. The projection of u⃗\vec{u}u onto v⃗\vec{v}v is defined by projv⃗(u⃗)=u⃗⋅v⃗∣∣v⃗∣∣2v⃗proj_{\vec{v}}(\vec{u})=\frac{\vec{u}\cdot\vec{v}}{||\vec{v}||^{2}}\vec{v}projv​(u)=∣∣v∣∣2u⋅v​v.

Let u⃗,v⃗∈Rn\vec{u},\vec{v}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}u,v∈Rn with v⃗≠0⃗\vec{v}\ne\vec{0}v=0. The perpendicular of u⃗\vec{u}u onto v⃗\vec{v}v is defined by perpv⃗(u⃗)=u⃗−projv⃗(u⃗)perp_{\vec{v}}(\vec{u})=\vec{u}-proj_{\vec{v}}(\vec{u})perpv​(u)=u−projv​(u)

e.g. Let u⃗=[−1−3]\vec{u}=\begin{bmatrix}-1\\ -3\end{bmatrix}u=[−1−3​] and v⃗=[11]\vec{v}=\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 1\end{bmatrix}v=[11​]. Find projv⃗(u⃗)proj_{\vec{v}}(\vec{u})projv​(u) and perpv⃗(u⃗)perp_{\vec{v}}(\vec{u})perpv​(u). Answer: projv⃗(u⃗)=u⃗⋅v⃗∣∣v⃗∣∣2v⃗=−42[11]=[−2−2]proj_{\vec{v}}(\vec{u})=\frac{\vec{u}\cdot\vec{v}}{||\vec{v}||^{2}}\vec{v}=\frac{-4}{2}\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 1\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}-2\\ -2\end{bmatrix}projv​(u)=∣∣v∣∣2u⋅v​v=2−4​[11​]=[−2−2​] perpv⃗(u⃗)=u⃗−projv⃗(u⃗)=[−1−3]−[−2−2]=[1−1]perp_{\vec{v}}(\vec{u})=\vec{u}-proj_{\vec{v}}(\vec{u})=\begin{bmatrix}-1\\ -3\end{bmatrix}-\begin{bmatrix}-2\\ -2\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}1\\ -1\end{bmatrix}perpv​(u)=u−projv​(u)=[−1−3​]−[−2−2​]=[1−1​]

Let P be a plane in R3\mathbb{R}^{3}R3 that passes through the origin and has normal vector n⃗\vec{n}n. The projection of x⃗∈R3\vec{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{3}x∈R3 onto P is defined by projP(x⃗)=perpn⃗(x⃗)proj_{P}(\vec{x})=perp_{\vec{n}}(\vec{x})projP​(x)=perpn​(x). The perpendicular of x⃗\vec{x}x onto P is defined by perpP(x⃗)=projn⃗(x⃗)perp_{P}(\vec{x})=proj_{\vec{n}}(\vec{x})perpP​(x)=projn​(x).

e.g. Find the projection of v⃗=[123]\vec{v}=\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 2\\ 3\end{bmatrix}v=​123​​ onto the plane P given by −2x1+x2+4x3=0-2x_{1}+x_{2}+4x_{3}=0−2x1​+x2​+4x3​=0. Answer: Let n⃗=[−214]\vec{n}=\begin{bmatrix}-2\\ 1\\ 4\end{bmatrix}n=​−214​​ be a normal vector to the plane. Then projn⃗(v⃗)=v⃗⋅n⃗∣∣n⃗∣∣2n⃗=1(−2)+2(1)+3(4)(−2)2+12+42[−214]=−2+2+124+1+16[−214]=1221[−214]=[−24/2112/2148/21]=[−8/74/716/7]proj_{\vec{n}}(\vec{v})=\frac{\vec{v}\cdot\vec{n}}{||\vec{n}||^2}\vec{n} = \frac{1(-2)+2(1)+3(4)}{(-2)^2+1^2+4^2}\begin{bmatrix}-2\\ 1\\ 4\end{bmatrix} = \frac{-2+2+12}{4+1+16}\begin{bmatrix}-2\\ 1\\ 4\end{bmatrix} = \frac{12}{21}\begin{bmatrix}-2\\ 1\\ 4\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}-24/21\\ 12/21\\ 48/21\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}-8/7\\ 4/7\\ 16/7\end{bmatrix}projn​(v)=∣∣n∣∣2v⋅n​n=(−2)2+12+421(−2)+2(1)+3(4)​​−214​​=4+1+16−2+2+12​​−214​​=2112​​−214​​=​−24/2112/2148/21​​=​−8/74/716/7​​ and projP(v⃗)=perpn⃗(v⃗)=v⃗−projn⃗(v⃗)=[123]−[−8/74/716/7]=[7/7+8/714/7−4/721/7−16/7]=[15/710/75/7]proj_{P}(\vec{v})=perp_{\vec{n}}(\vec{v})=\vec{v}-proj_{\vec{n}}(\vec{v})=\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 2\\ 3\end{bmatrix}-\begin{bmatrix}-8/7\\ 4/7\\ 16/7\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}7/7+8/7\\ 14/7-4/7\\ 21/7-16/7\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}15/7\\ 10/7\\ 5/7\end{bmatrix}projP​(v)=perpn​(v)=v−projn​(v)=​123​​−​−8/74/716/7​​=​7/7+8/714/7−4/721/7−16/7​​=​15/710/75/7​​ .
